div1.p:
The model must have been
made when our troops were
there in 1906 - 08. The y f.
buildings are too far west of R R.
and the two rows are too far apart

The model as it is assembled at Carlisle
Bks. is very inaccurate. The buildings
are well done and those that were there
in my time are readily recognizable.
They are, however all crowded together,
when in reality the distances were
great. For example the distance from
the Med. officers quarters (1) to wards
was about 240 ft. and from the flag pole
to Reed's lab. was about 180 ft. yds? I know
this because Reed asked me to have the
distance measured and he reported the
distance in describing Carroll's walk to the
Lab. when to examine his (Carroll's) blood
on Aug 31, 1900. (See Preliminary Report.)

As the buildings are arranged on
this sheet, I think you will find that
all the old timers will agree that it
is fairly good, if not almost accurate.
Of course, I realize that, the sections
of the model could not possibly be
arranged to fit the rectangular case you described
and at the same time be accurate.
It is possible that Sr. Perez arranged
Expected that the parts of the model
would be set up correctly in the U. S. and
that someone assembled them in
the U. S. from written instructions, but
without any conception of the
general plan of the grounds.

You will find that the arrangement
heron corresponds very well with
the plan of the grounds I sent you.
Several of the old men have set me
straight on the location of the barracks
and the old small box building, used
in 1900 by Ames to treat the cases from
Camp Lazear. Earlier Ames had
preferred framed tents to the shacks.

I am trying to find out if Lazear died
in one of the 4 buildings or in a tent. I can't
remember- I know the man who assisted in his case when sick, Hope I can locate him.
